title: Pic de Gerlache
text:
Pic de Gerlache is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in <a href="%20King%20Frederick%20VIII%20Land"> King Frederick VIII Land</a>, NE <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>. Administratively it is part of the <a href="Northeast%20Greenland%20National%20Park">Northeast Greenland National Park</a>. 
History.
This nunatak was named in 1905 by the <a href="Prince%20Philippe%2C%20Duke%20of%20Orl%C3%A9ans%20%281869%E2%80%931926%29">Duke of Orléans</a> during his <a href="Duke%20of%20Orl%C3%A9ans%20Arctic%20Expedition">Arctic Expedition</a> on ship <a href="RV%20Belgica%20%281884%29">Belgica</a>, when he explored parts of the northeastern coast of Greenland. He named it after Belgian explorer <a href="Adrien%20de%20Gerlache">Adrien de Gerlache</a> (1866–1934).
Although this peak was an important landmark for the first explorers of the area, the 1906–08 <a href="Danmark%20Expedition">Danmark Expedition</a> was unable to identify the original peak. Since the expedition members considered that the name should be preserved, it was placed on a conspicuous mountain rising on the north side of <a href="Gammel%20Hellerup%20Glacier">Gammel Hellerup Glacier</a>.
A few years later, <a href="Ejnar%20Mikkelsen">Ejnar Mikkelsen</a> described this mountain as a <a href="Pyramid%20%28geometry%29">pyramid</a> during the 1909-12 <a href="Alabama%20Expedition">Alabama Expedition</a>: 
Geography.
Pic de Gerlache is located in Norre Biland, the northern section of <a href="Duke%20of%20Orleans%20Land">Duke of Orleans Land</a>. It rises from a <a href="nunatak">nunatak</a> a few kilometers inland in the central zone of <a href="Jokel%20Bay">Jokel Bay</a>. On some maps the name is misplaced westwards to a slightly higher but less prominent nunatak peak.
